ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This class was an in depth advanced E&M class. It reviewed electro and magento statics although I never really feel like I was comfortable with those topics to begin with so it gave some background there, AC circuits and time varying fields, transmission lines, plane waves, waveguides, and some antenna stuff at the very end. I think if you have a brain for physics you may actually get a lot from this class; however, struggle as I do with physics concepts, you might end up feeling like this is more of a survey... you've seen the equations for a broad range of E&M topics but are comfortable with very few of them. 
Definitely a course built around maxwell's equations!
I got a more in-depth understanding of E&M, as well as Maxwell's Equations.
A bit more physics. It built upon E&M.

This class covered all of electrostatics and magnetostatics, then we explored waves, light, transmission lines, waveguides, and a bit of antennas. We learned a lot about the applications of Maxwell's Equations and how all of this physics is used in the real world.
Deriving electromagnetic physics equations from first principles, applying vector calculus, deeper insight into Maxwell's equations
I learned about electromagnetic waves and devices, specifically transmission lines, plane waves, electric fieds/magnetic fields, etc.
Learned about electromagnetism

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
My biggest qualm with this class was that it was very centered around physics majors or physics backgrounds despite being a required course for the ABET EE degree (with a population of EE students dominating other majors). That means we sped quickly through "basic" E&M topics and often glossed over foundational information but spent a lot of time on things like deriving expressions for certain circuit elements or the like. It's tough because I think the class was actually very well taught and very well organized (and fair for the most part), it's just a little too lofty for EEs who have minimal physics background. I often felt like I was too confused or too unaware of the context of the lecture to ask effective questions. This was a common feeling amongst EEs I think. 
I think the only solutions are giving the EEs more physics background before the course or pairing down the course topics a little so we can go slower through some of the basics.
This course moves very fast and the resources available for help in it are limited.

I thought that it was very challenging in a virtual environment, and there was a lot of material which we could have engaged with more deeply.  The hardest part of the class was the homework because I don't feel like the lectures or reading would adequately prepare us for the homework problems.  Often times, the homework led to more confusion, rather than more clarity.
I wish it focused more on applications like antennas. I also wish there were more real problems with numbers instead of theoretical derivations of equations.

This course was extremely mathematical and rigorous, but there really is no other way to teach the material. I think that the class could have moved a little slower - I often felt like I was just racing to copy down equations as they were written, and would have to try and understand them later. The homework was good practice for exams, and was usually harder than stuff we covered in class, so that it really reinforced material.

Strength - The physics build on each topic, so if you truly understand the foundations (Maxwell equations) then everything else will eventually make sense (i.e. don't have to "memorize" lots of data)

Weakness - Only six psets, due to scheduling limitations, and I felt we did not really practice all the topics in problem solving. (There are plenty of examples in the Griffiths textbook though, so I could rely on that)

Strengths: the strong community created by the class. We worked long hours together on psets and preparing for exams, and it really made the class special

Weaknesses: no office hours with professor Schoelkopf, only 2 hours a week with the TA, Yanni. The class moves really quickly so if you don't have a really solid physics/ee background it can be hard to keep up

Strengths: in-depth coverage of material
Weaknesses: The workload, especially for this semester, dismissed how difficult this semester was for students. We covered an excess of material, which bled into "break days." The priority was therefore given to finishing the initial predicted coursework rather than giving students enough time to absorb or even learn the material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that the professor adapted well to the students and their needs, and I think that's what makes a course successful.

This class went over pretty well virtually. Unfortunately we missed a number of in person demonstrations that are normally a part of the course, but sometimes they were supplemented with videos or good descriptions. However, there's nothing quite like sitting alone in your dorm hearing about how cool a demonstration is, and then not being able to see it live since we weren't in a classroom..... that was no fun to hear. However, the lectures were fine to take remotely, and the notes were solid.
The lectures worked out well, standard pset course. A bit unfortunate that we did not see "live" demonstrations of electromagnetic phenomena, though these can be searched on YouTube quickly.

the recorded lectures was actually really helpful because I could go back to them when preparing for exams, and also if I was watching recorded it was incredibly helpful to be able to pause/replay more confusing parts
The class was not accommodating during the Mental Health crisis at Yale and was inflexible in accommodating to the difficulties of this semester.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I personally just despise physics and was taking this class in order to finish my major. The course really was as horrible as I expected but to no fault of the prof or course organization in general  just due to my own ineptitude on this subject, COVID preventing in person classes, and my senioritis. 
My stance is this: Rob seems to be a good lecturer, his psets and tests are killer but honestly what's new, the topics covered seem like they are important if you want to be an E&M physicist or if you love E&M as a topic. If you are one of those people then sure go for it, there is nothing fundamentally wrong with this class. 
If you didn't like intro physics but you are thinking that maybe this class will spark your love of physics I would say just save yourself the misery. If you are an EE taking this in your senior spring as a requirement, RIP.
Yes, if it is required for your major or if you have a solid understanding go electromagnetism before taking this.
I would recommend it for those to whom need it for their major or research/career interests.
No, it's very difficult and I didn't feel like I gained much from the material. My peers had better experiences in similar courses at Yale in the Physics department.

I would recommend this class to engineers and physicists. The material covered is so essential to how our modern world works. However, it is also a very difficult course, and will chew up a lot of your time.
If you want a strong grasp of the physics behind electronic devices, and not be intimidated by vector calculus equations, yes! Be prepared for quite a bit of work and self-study.
yes. The support available for the class is not great, but overall I still learned a ton and grew a lot throughout the semester.

This course has a very heavy workload. Be prepared to spend a lot of time preparing for exams and the extensive readings, PSETS, and lecture preparation. In the beginning of the course, we cover about a lecture per day. This was quite overwhelming, especially during the pandemic. It is a thorough review of E&M, but packed into way too short a time.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We started the semester doing flipped classroom style virtual learning where we would watch recorded lectures and then attend actual class on zoom to discuss. Eventually, the class decided they preferred lectures to happen only live on zoom during class and we stopped having the online pre-recorded lecture component.
recorded and live lectures
At the beginning, we did both recorded lectures and in-person review during class time.
Live lectures that were recorded, some recorded at the beginning as well.
By live lecture and some recorded lectures at first
The live virtual lecture was also recorded
Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture
